name: Sudarshana Chakra
shortDescription: Vishnu's divine discus weapon with 108 serrated edges, representing cosmic order and time
fullDescription: The Sudarshana Chakra (Sanskrit: ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§® ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞, 'Auspicious Vision Disc') is the divine discus weapon of Lord Vishnu, one of the most powerful weapons in Hindu mythology. This spinning disc possesses 108 serrated edges that can cut through anything, both material and spiritual. The Chakra represents the wheel of time (kala-chakra), the cycle of creation and destruction, and Vishnu's role as the preserver of cosmic order. It is said to be self-powered, eternally spinning, and possessing unlimited energy. When thrown, the Sudarshana Chakra pursues its target with unfailing accuracy, can multiply itself to attack multiple enemies simultaneously, and returns to Vishnu's hand after completing its mission. The weapon is personified as a deity and considered an extension of Vishnu's will.

mythologyContexts.usage: The Sudarshana Chakra is Vishnu's primary weapon for destroying evil and protecting dharma. It is wielded by Vishnu's avatars including Krishna (who beheaded Shishupala with it) and is depicted resting on Vishnu's finger, eternally spinning. The Chakra represents the mind, which must be controlled and directed to achieve spiritual liberation.

rituals.name: Slaying of Shishupala
rituals.description: Krishna used the Sudarshana Chakra to behead Shishupala after he insulted Krishna 100 times

rituals.name: Protection of Draupadi
rituals.description: Krishna sent the Chakra to protect Draupadi's honor

mythologyContexts.symbolism: The Sudarshana Chakra's circular form represents the eternal nature of time and the cyclical nature of existence. Its 108 edges correspond to the 108 Upanishads, 108 names of deities, and the sacred number in Hinduism representing spiritual completion. The spinning motion symbolizes the restless nature of the mind, which must be controlled and focused like Vishnu controls the Chakra. Its ability to destroy evil represents the power of divine knowledge to cut through ignorance and maya.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: The Sudarshana Chakra is one of the most recognizable symbols of Vaishnavism, appearing in temple iconography, religious art, and as a protective symbol. It is worshiped as a deity (Sudarshana Bhagavan) in its own right in some traditions. The Chakra is invoked for protection and is believed to destroy negative energies and evil influences.
